conclusion: To determine when the two waves meet, we need to calculate the travel time for each wave to reach the point where they will be superimposed.
The left wave starts at x = -0.2 m.
The right wave starts at x = 1.2 m.
Assume the waves will meet at a point where their travel times are equal, consider the center of the system at x = 0.5 m.
The left wave travels from x = -0.2 m to x = 0.5 m, Distance_left = 0.7 m.
The right wave travels from x = 1.2 m to x = 0.5 m, Distance_right = -0.7 m.
The absolute distances are the same: |Distance_left| = 0.7 m, |Distance_right| = 0.7 m.
Time taken by the left wave: t_left = Distance_left / Speed = 0.7 m / 0.4 m/s = 1.75 s.
Time taken by the right wave: t_right = Distance_right / Speed = 0.7 m / 0.4 m/s = 1.75 s.
Since both waves take the same time to reach the meeting point, the two waves will meet after 1.75 s.
